answers.author: Steve Fisher
answers.text:
Usability is different from accessibility, though an accessible site can be more usable, so the links Matthew Vanderhost included won't really address usability.  I can't recommend any particular professional service, as I have done usability testing on my own internally.

answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
A couple of suggestions to stimulate "blue sky" thinking on this topic.  
The Fun Theory website (http://www.thefuntheory.com/) highlights techniques for getting people to change their behaviors.  In this case, you're wanting citizens to use your website more.
Bill Buxton (http://www.billbuxton.com/) has done research looking at the user's experience with websites.
Finally, the Public Technology Institute (PTI) has criteria for website evaluation that they've developed.  You can learn more at http://www.pti.org/index.php/ptiee1/inside/C29 .
